abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. 1) Complex institutional change needs careful
            design, preparation & long term commitment. 2)  A
            learning-by-doing approach is the best way to facilitate
            devolution. The first Mindanao Rural Development Project
            (MRDP 1) provides an operational model on how a national
            sectoral agency like the Department of Agriculture can
            decentralize functions and responsibilities. 3) Well-defined
            and constructive partnership between national government
            agencies and local governments is key to effective
            devolution. 4) Strengthening grass roots organizations,
            local governments and communities is vital to meaningful
            participatory and integrated development. 5) Using regular
            government personnel, instead of contracted personnel
            provides for greater institutionalization of project
            initiatives. 6) Effective operation and use of a
            well-designed monitoring and evaluation system hinge on the
            adequacy of the budget, good quality staff, and a high level
            of prioritization. 7) Disbursements and financial management
            are better facilitated if  technical implementation and
            financial management, are tightly linked and monitored by
            qualified staff right at the beginning of implementation.

5086133.trustfund:
TF025525-PHRD-MINDANAO RURAL DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF026782-JSDF-PHILIPPINES: IMPROVING
            MICROFINANCE ACCESS FOR BARANGAY- AND TOWN-
5086133.majtheme: Public sector governance,Rural development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Mindanao Rural Development Project
            aims to increase the income and improve food security of
            targeted agricultural and fishermen communities in the
            Philippines, thus restoring economic growth through poverty
            reduction and equity improvement. The main components are:
            rehabilitation of rural roads and farm-to-market access
            roads, ensuring that provincial roads meet essential
            criteria and link to existing all-weather roads. Communal
            irrigation will be supported through improved management and
            schemes maintenance. Spring development projects will
            provide safe potable water to the communities, while water,
            sanitation, and health associations' management and
            institutional development will be strengthened; 2) the
            Community Funds for Agricultural Development will be
            established to address priorities of the communities. The
            funds will be provided initially, from loan proceeds, and
            municipal contributions, to support agricultural and
            fisheries development, particularly targeting, poor
            communities, specifically women, and indigenous groups; 3)
            institutional and implementation support, to strengthen
            local capacity of micro-finance institutions; enhancement of
            rural development planning, and resource allocation; and,
            financial management assistance; and 4) coastal
            bio-diversity conservation, whose incremental costs, will be
            financed by the Global Environmental Facility (GEF).

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Mindanao Rural Development
            Project (APL) : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Mindanao Rural Development Project details the negative
            environmental impacts resulting from water supply and road
            construction and recommends mitigation measures. Careful
            planning will minimize and offset impairment of cultural and
            historical sites. During the design phase, the area
            surrounding the spring box and reservoir will be fenced to
            prevent traffic by people or stray animals and act as a
            barrier to runoff that could possibly contaminate the
            source. To reduce soil erosion from exposed areas and
            deterioration of water quality, soil filled trenches should
            be compacted and vegetation planted. Flooding of lots and
            farmlands adjacent to roads will be mitigated by carefully
            planning drainage facilities, and including bridges, box
            culverts, reinforced concrete pipes, and side ditches.
            Properly storing spoils and using silting ponds will
            alleviate stream sedimentation. Dust will be controlled by
            spraying road surfaces and imposing speed limits on
            motorists. No protection measures are recommended to
            mitigate against deforestation and other losses of
            agricultural lands and ecology due to road construction, but
            offsetting actions are planned during spring development. To
            prevent social conflict arising from water use distribution,
            limited water rights will be offered. Social inequities
            resulting from resettlement will be checked by careful planning.

Philippines - Mindanao Rural Development

439090.trustfund:
TF026782-JSDF-PHILIPPINES: IMPROVING
            MICROFINANCE ACCESS FOR BARANGAY- AND TOWN-,TF025525-PHRD-MINDANAO RURAL DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF025069-PHRD-MINDANAO RURAL DEV. PROJ.(REC.-EXEC)

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Mindanao Rural Development
            Project (APL) : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Mindanao Rural Development Project details the negative
            environmental impacts resulting from water supply and road
            construction and recommends mitigation measures. Careful
            planning will minimize and offset impairment of cultural and
            historical sites. During the design phase, the area
            surrounding the spring box and reservoir will be fenced to
            prevent traffic by people or stray animals and act as a
            barrier to runoff that could possibly contaminate the
            source. To reduce soil erosion from exposed areas and
            deterioration of water quality, soil filled trenches should
            be compacted and vegetation planted. Flooding of lots and
            farmlands adjacent to roads will be mitigated by carefully
            planning drainage facilities, and including bridges, box
            culverts, reinforced concrete pipes, and side ditches.
            Properly storing spoils and using silting ponds will
            alleviate stream sedimentation. Dust will be controlled by
            spraying road surfaces and imposing speed limits on
            motorists. No protection measures are recommended to
            mitigate against deforestation and other losses of
            agricultural lands and ecology due to road construction, but
            offsetting actions are planned during spring development. To
            prevent social conflict arising from water use distribution,
            limited water rights will be offered. Social inequities
            resulting from resettlement will be checked by careful planning.
